titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

publicationstmt.publisher: Free Library of Philadelphia, Map Collection

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

did.repository: Free Library of Philadelphia, Map Collection

bioghist.p: The United States Geologic Survey took over responsibility for mapping the country in 1879 and has been the primary civilian mapping agency of the United States ever since. The best known USGS maps are the 1:24,000-scale topographic maps, also known as 7.5-minute quadrangles. More than 55,000 7.5-minute maps were made to cover the 48 conterminous States. This is the only uniform map series that covers the entire area of the United States in considerable detail. The 7.5-minute map series was officially completed in 1992.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of United States Geologic Survey maps. Materials include: current 1:24,000 scale maps for all U.S. states and territories; historical 1:24,000 scale maps for Pennsylvania, Delaware, New Jersey, and Maryland (7.5 minute series); older 15 minute series maps for many areas (mostly 1950s-1990s; historical maps go back to 1894); 1:100,000 scale maps for various quadrangles of the U.S. states (mostly 1970s-1990s); and 1:250.000 scale maps for various quadrangles of the U.S. states (mostly 1970s-1990s).

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
